title: Latest nightly (`rustc 1.64.0-nightly (62b272d25 2022-07-21)`) introduces a new borrowcheck error in previously compiling `mdbook` `0.4.20`

labels.name: regression-from-stable-to-stable
labels.description: Performance or correctness regression from one stable version to another.

labels.name: I-prioritize
labels.description: Indicates that prioritization has been requested for this issue

body:
As of `rustc 1.64.0-nightly (62b272d25 2022-07-21)`, a new lifetime error has appeared when attempting to build `mdbook` `0.4.20`.

### Error

```
error[E0597]: `local_ctx` does not live long enough
   --> src/renderer/html_handlebars/helpers/navigation.rs:154:25
    |
154 |             t.render(r, &local_ctx, &mut local_rc, out)
    |                         ^^^^^^^^^^ borrowed value does not live long enough
155 |         })?;
    |         -
    |         |
    |         `local_ctx` dropped here while still borrowed
    |         borrow might be used here, when `local_rc` is dropped and runs the destructor for type `handlebars::RenderContext<'_, '_>`
    |
    = note: values in a scope are dropped in the opposite order they are defined

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0597`.
error: could not compile `mdbook` due to previous error
```

### Version it worked on

rustc 1.64.0-nightly (d68e7ebc3 2022-07-20)

### Version with regression

rustc 1.64.0-nightly (62b272d25 2022-07-21)

### Details

You can find more details at the downstream `mdbook` issue https://github.com/rust-lang/mdBook/issues/1860.

Curiously, the new error can be fixed by re-ordering some seemingly inocuous statements - see this PR https://github.com/rust-lang/mdBook/pull/1861.

Perhaps this is indicative of an error in non-lexical-lifetime handling on the latest nightly? Or alternatively, this could be the result of fixing a soundness / safety issue related to the interop between lifetimes and drop order?

This error was originally discovered in an unrelated CI pass failing in the following PR: https://github.com/FuelLabs/sway/pull/2359.
